HTTPAuth package#

Submodules#

HTTPAuth.client module#

class HTTPAuth.client.Auth(url: str, session_file: str)#

Bases: object

Base Class for Client-Side Authentication.

This module is to be used for authentication requests to a server which uses/supports HTTPAuth.server

Parameters:

  • url: str (The URL of the server)

  • session_file: str (The file path where the client session will be stored. Must be a ‘.JSON’ file.)

auth(name: str, location: str = 'None')#

Authenticates the Client with the Server and establishes a secure connection.

Parameters:

  • name: str (Name of the Client)

  • location: str = ‘None’ (Location of the Client)

Example:

from HTTPAuth.client import Auth as ClientAuth
client = ClientAuth(url, session_file)
client.auth(name, location)
load_session()#

Loads the saved session from the session file.

Example:

from HTTPAuth.client import Auth as ClientAuth
client = ClientAuth(url, session_file)
client.load_session()
make_request(method: Literal['GET', 'OPTIONS', 'HEAD', 'POST', 'PUT', 'PATCH', 'DELETE'], endpoint: str, headers: dict, **kwargs)#

Makes a secure request to the server by encrypting the headers being sent to the server and decrypting the data received from the server.

Parameters:

  • method: Literal[‘GET’, ‘OPTIONS’, ‘HEAD’, ‘POST, ‘PUT’, ‘PATCH’, ‘DELETE’] (The method to make the request with)

  • endpoint: str (The endpoint to make a request to)

  • headers: dict (The headers received to send to the server)

Example:

from HTTPAuth.client import Auth as ClientAuth
client = ClientAuth(url, session_file)
client.auth(name, location)
response: dict = client.make_request('GET', endpoint, headers)
save_session(passphrase: bytes = b'passphrase')#

Saves the current Client status/session in the session file.

Parameters:

  • passphrase: bytes = b”passphrase” (Passphrase to decode the private key before converting it to bytes)

Example:

from HTTPAuth.client import Auth as ClientAuth
client = ClientAuth(url, session_file)
# Optional: Authorize the client using `client.auth()`
client.save_session(passphrase)

HTTPAuth.server module#

class HTTPAuth.server.Auth(app, store_tokens_func=<function ExtraUtils.save_token>, load_tokens_func=<function ExtraUtils.load_raw_data>, token_file: str | None = None, server_name: str = 'Flask Test Server', server_location: str = 'None')#

Bases: object

Base class for Server-Side HTTP Authentication.

This module is to be used for processing authentication requests sent by a client which uses/supports HTTPAuth.client

Parameters:

  • app: Flask (The Flask App)

  • store_tokens_func: function = save_token (The function to store tokens.)

  • load_tokens_func: function = load_raw_data (The function to load tokens.)

  • token_file: str = None (Only required if store_tokens_func and load_tokens_func are not defined. The file path where the user tokens are to be stored. Must be a .json file)

  • server_name: str = ‘Flask Test Server’ (Name of the server)

  • server_location: str = ‘None’ (Location of the Server)

Note: If a different function is assigned for store_tokens_func, then the function must contain one parameter which accepts the raw data. This raw data can be stored in any format as required.

Note: If a different function is assigned for load_tokens_func, then the function must return the data in the same format and as the raw data provided. It must be a dict with the following structure:

{

token:

{

‘Key’: key,

‘Expiry’: expiry

}

}

disable_logs()#

Enables Log records for authentication requests.

Parameters:

  • log_file: str (The file path where the log records are to be stored)

  • print_logs: bool = False (Bool indicating whether the log records are to be printed or not)

Example:

from HTTPAuth.server import Auth as ServerAuth
from flask import Flask
app = Flask(__name__)
server = ServerAuth(app=app, token_file=token_file)
server.register_auth_routes(app, token_file, server_name, server_location)

Warns:

Logs are already disabled!

enable_logs(log_file: str, print_logs: bool = False)#

Enables Log records for authentication requests.

Parameters:

  • log_file: str (The file path where the log records are to be stored)

  • print_logs: bool = False (Bool indicating whether the log records are to be printed or not)

Example:

from HTTPAuth.server import Auth as ServerAuth
from flask import Flask
app = Flask(__name__)
server = ServerAuth(app=app, token_file=token_file)
server.register_auth_routes(app, token_file, server_name, server_location)

Warns:

Logs are already enabled!

register_auth_routes()#

Registers the endpoints/routes for client authentication in the server side.

Is to be used for processing authentication requests sent by a client using HTTPAuth.client.

Example:

from flask import Flask
from HTTPAuth.server import Auth as ServerAuth
app = Flask(__name__)
token_file = './tokens.json'
server = ServerAuth(app=app, token_file=token_file)
server.register_auth_routes()
route(rule: str, headers_to_accept: list[str], key_not_found: Literal['set value to None', 'return Invalid Headers to Client', 'raise Exception'], include_token: bool = False, **options)#

Creates a Flask endpoint which decrypts the data being received by the endpoint as headers and encrypts the data being sent by the endpoint as data to the client.

Parameters:

  • rule: str (The endpoint)

  • headers_to_accept: list[str] (The headers to receive and decrypt)

  • key_not_found: (The action to perform when a key in headers_to_accept is not found in the request headers)

    • set value to None: Sets the corresponding key value to None

    • return Invalid Headers to Client: Returns an Invalid Headers 400 error to the client

    • raise Exception: Raises an Exception and returns status code 500 to the client.

  • include_token: bool (Indicates whether the token is to be included in the final headers or not)

Note: The view function when using @server.route should ALWAYS have the following three parameters:

  • headers: dict (Contains the decrypted headers)

  • *args: tuple (Contains the positional arguments passed to the view function when using @app.route)

  • **kwargs: dict (Contains the keyword arguments passed to the view function when using @app.route)

Note: The output of the view function of @server.route should always be a dict serialized to a str (preferrably using json.dumps). All the keys and values of the original dict should be str.

Example 1:

from HTTPAuth.server import Auth as ServerAuth
from flask import Flask
app = Flask(__name__)
server = ServerAuth(app=app, token_file=token_file)
server.register_auth_routes()
@server.route(rule="/", headers_to_accept=headers_to_accept, key_not_found=Literal['set value to None', 'return Invalid Headers to Client', 'raise Exception'], include_token=include_token, methods=['GET', 'POST', ...])
def test(headers, *args, **kwargs): # The view function always has to have the given three parameters.
    ...
    return json.dumps(data) #Each value of each key in the data (dict) variable should be a string.

Example 2:

from HTTPAuth.server import Auth as ServerAuth
from flask import Flask
app = Flask(__name__)
server = ServerAuth(app=app, token_file=token_file)
server.register_auth_routes()
@server.route(rule="/<param>", headers_to_accept=headers_to_accept, key_not_found=Literal['set value to None', 'return Invalid Headers to Client', 'raise Exception'], include_token=include_token, methods=['GET', 'POST', ...])
def test(headers, *args, **kwargs): # The view function always has to have the given three parameters.
    param = kwargs['param']
    ...
    return json.dumps(data) #Each value of each key in the data (dict) variable should be a string.
update_logs(entry: str)#

Updates the logs with the given log entry.

Parameters:

  • entry: str (The log entry to record)

Example:

from HTTPAuth.server import Auth as ServerAuth
from flask import Flask
app = Flask(__name__)
server = ServerAuth(app=app, token_file=token_file)
server.enable_logs(log_file=log_file, False)
server.update_logs(entry)

HTTPAuth.server_utils module#

class HTTPAuth.server_utils.CA#

Bases: object

Acts as the CA for server and client certificate generation.

Not meant to be imported for use aside from inside the module.

create_client_certificate(client_public_key_bytes: bytes, client_name: str, client_location: str = 'None')#

Creates a certificate for the Client.

Parameters:

  • public_key_bytes: bytes (The client’s public key in bytes)

  • name: str (Name of the client)

  • location: str (Location of the client)

Example:

from HTTPAuth.server_utils.ca import CA
ca = CA()
client_certificate = ca.create_client(public_key_bytes=public_key_bytes, name, location)
create_server_certificate(public_key_bytes: bytes, name: str, location: str = 'None') → dict[str, str]#

Creates a certificate for the Server.

Parameters:

  • public_key_bytes: bytes (The server’s public key in bytes)

  • name: str (Name of the server)

  • location: str (Location of the server)

Example:

from HTTPAuth.server_utils.ca import CA
ca = CA()
server_certificate = ca.create_server_certificate(public_key_bytes=public_key_bytes, name, location)
class HTTPAuth.server_utils.ExtraUtils#

Bases: object

Base class for extra server utilities

form_raw_data(symmetric_key: bytes, expiry: str, load_tokens_func, tokenfile) → dict#

Forms encrypted raw data from the loaded raw data.

Parameters:

  • token: str (The user token)

  • symmetric_key: bytes (The symmetric key of the user token)

  • expiry: str (The expiry date of the user token)

  • load_tokens_func: function (The function assigned to load the tokens)

  • tokenfile: str (The file path where the user tokens are stored)

generate_session_token()#

Generates a session token of desired length.

Parameters:

  • length: int (The desired length of the session token)

load_raw_data() → dict#

Default function to load raw data from the token file.

Can be replaced with a custom function to load raw data while intializing Server object.

Parameters:

  • tokenfile: str (The file path where the user tokens are stored.)

save_token(tokenfile: str)#

Default function to save tokens to the token file.

Can be replaced with a custom function to save tokens while intializing Server object.

Parameters:

  • tokenfile: str (The file path where the user tokens are stored.)

validate_client_certificate(server: Server)#

Validates the client certificate

Parameters:

  • certificate: dict[str, str] (The decrypted client certificate in the form of a dict)

  • server: Server (The initialized Server object)

validate_loaded_raw_data()#

Validates the raw data loaded.

Parameters:

  • raw_data: dict (The raw data.)

class HTTPAuth.server_utils.Server(name: str, location: str = 'None')#

Bases: object

Initializes the server.

create_certificate(server_public_key_bytes: bytes) → None#

Creates a certificate for the server from the CA.

Parameters:

  • server_public_key_bytes: bytes (The server’s public key in bytes)

Example:

from HTTPAuth.server_utils.server import Server
server = Server()
server.create_certificate(server_public_key_bytes=server_public_key_bytes)
